ch_gram_a1_01.title: Nouns and Articles
ch_gram_a1_01.theory:
## Gender of Spanish Nouns

All Spanish nouns are either **masculine (masculino)** or **feminine (femenino)**.

### Definite Articles (Artículos definidos)
| | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | el | los |
| Feminine | la | las |

### Indefinite Articles (Artículos indefinidos)
| | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | un | unos |
| Feminine | una | unas |

### Rules
- Nouns ending in **-o** → usually masculine: el libro, el gato
- Nouns ending in **-a** → usually feminine: la casa, la mesa
- Exceptions: el día, el mapa, la mano

ch_gram_a1_02.title: Subject Pronouns and the Verb Ser
ch_gram_a1_02.title_es: Pronombres personales y el verbo ser
ch_gram_a1_02.theory:
## Subject Pronouns (Pronombres personales)

| Person | Singular | Plural |
|---|---|---|
| 1st | yo | nosotros/nosotras |
| 2nd | tú | vosotros/vosotras |
| 3rd | él/ella/usted | ellos/ellas/ustedes |

> Spanish often omits the subject pronoun since verb conjugation indicates who is speaking.

## Ser - Present Tense Conjugation

| Person | Conjugation |
|---|---|
| yo | soy |
| tú | eres |
| él/ella/usted | es |
| nosotros/as | somos |
| vosotros/as | sois |
| ellos/ellas/ustedes | son |

### Uses of Ser
- **Essential traits**: Ella es inteligente. (She is smart)
- **Profession**: Yo soy profesor. (I am a teacher)
- **Nationality**: Nosotros somos coreanos. (We are Korean)
- **Time**: Son las tres. (It's three o'clock)
key_points: Subject pronouns are often omitted in Spanish
ser: essential traits, profession, nationality, time

ch_vocab_a1_01.title: Greetings and Basic Expressions
ch_vocab_a1_01.theory:
## Basic Greetings

Let's learn the most common Spanish greetings.

### Time-based Greetings
- **Buenos días** - Good morning
- **Buenas tardes** - Good afternoon
- **Buenas noches** - Good evening / Good night

### Meeting and Parting
- **¡Hola!** - Hi! (informal)
- **¿Qué tal?** - How's it going?
- **¡Adiós!** - Goodbye!
- **¡Hasta luego!** - See you later!
- **¡Hasta mañana!** - See you tomorrow!

### Thanks and Apologies
- **Gracias** - Thank you
- **Muchas gracias** - Thank you very much
- **De nada** - You're welcome
- **Perdón / Disculpe** - Excuse me / Sorry
key_points: ¡Hola! can be used at any time of day
Use different greetings based on time of day

vocab_list.example_meaning: Thank you very much for your help.
